too stupid!! Conservatives favor capitalism and freedom and that produces huge changes.Look at China now that they have switched to conservative capitalism. Its the most dynamic society on earth now that they are done with liberalism.

 
 Uh.....first of all, introducing capitalism to china would be a liberal move, not a conservative one. Keeping their old communist system would be the conservative move. You dont seem to know what either of those terms actually mean. I would suggest you actually LOOK THEM UP because I have to tell you, you look like a complete and utter jackass trying to claim that the founding fathers were conservative. 
 
 Second of all, China is not a capitalist country. It is hard to say what China is. They do not classify themselves as capitalist (they say they are market communists). The WTO does not classify them as capitalists. The US government does not classify them as capitalists. 
 
 Their state directed economy is a lot closer to a Fascist economic system than anything else, but even that does not fit because there is no corporatism. 
 
 The truth is that the Chinese economy is, for all intents and purposes, something NEW. You can not really even call them a "mixed" economy like you see in many European nations because typically for a mixed economy wealth distribution is modified via taxation and defined benefits. That is not china. 
 
 Currently over 90% of business loans in China are made by state owned banks, and by agreement roughly half those loans are nonperforming. The chinese government literally find people they think can run a billion dollar business, gives them a billion dollars, and turns them loose. Even that is not the wealth allocation via taxation you see in mixed economies because by leveraging their fractional reserve banking system to make the loans, they are not using anybodies tax dollars. They are literally printing the money, transferring the loans to the central bank, who then drops them off the balance sheet. 
 
 There are certainly some capitalist components to the chinese economic system, but when your government controls the VAST majority of your financial system, government officials literally call you to tell you how much to pay your people, how much of your product to produce, delivers R&D to your doorstep, sets your prices, and settles worker disputes by sending a government official to run your company and get things back on track, that aint capitalism.
 
 If you had actually taken any of those economic classes you recommend for others, you would recognize how novel and exciting the chinese system is. We are literally seeing the formation of a NEW economic system, and by all standards an incredibly successful one. As it matures, it seems likely that the Chinese system, whatever we end up calling it, will probably replace capitalism as the worlds most successful economic system. The efficiency gains they get from central direction are incredible. They do not have 5000 companies all researching different types of solar cells and hoping to come up with something new. Instead they figure out which research avenues are the most promising, pull the best R&D people that those companies have to offer, the government throws billions of dollars at it, and they come up with the solutions they are looking for. There is no duplicate effort. As long as the research continues to look promising they continue funding it at whatever level is needed. Stuff gets DONE.

1) if women work for less but do equal work consumers get lower prices thanks to women
 
 2) if men cost more to hire there are fewer jobs for men and more for women which is bad for men, not women, so how are women discriminated against
 
 3) if women do equal work for less, then other employers will want them, to beat competition, and so bid up wages to parity.
 
 Conclusion: the Republican free market handles the matter perfectly with no need for liberal socialist intervention

 
 And yet, it hasn't. We have data on gender payroll disparity going back to 1952, and women have always gotten the short end of the stick, despite the fact that we have data going back to 1963 that shows consistently that women are more productive than male employees. 
 
 The problem is that capitalist theory, or free market theory, requires that everybody always make the decision that makes the most economic sense. That is unrealistic. Most Americans do not even know how to TELL which decision makes the most economic sense. They have no idea. They just do things with no clue what the ramifications are. That is why less than 2% of the companies in our stock market can justify their valuation with a fundamental analysis. That is why we just had a massive housing bubble. Those people buying those houses pretty clearly did not make the decision that makes the most economic sense. Those people buying the MBS paper CERTAINLY did not make the decision that made the most economic sense. 
 
 The sole purpose of a market economy is price discovery, and the markets price discovery broke down COMPLETELY. Assets were literally priced at thousands of times their actual worth. 
 
 So, in a way, you could be right. If everybody made decisions based solely on what makes the most sense economically, the lower wages that women are paid would ultimately turn out to be a good thing for women. Since that is not the case, and only a fool would believe it was, you are not right, you are a fool.
